chapter.htmlHeader: Scenario: Management of abnormal vaginal discharge
chapter.summary: Covers the management of women and girls (12 years of age or older) with abnormal vaginal discharge.
chapter.htmlStringContent: From age 12 years onwards (Female).

chapters.fullItemName: Have I got the right topic?

subChapters.htmlHeader: How should I manage a woman with abnormal vaginal discharge?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Consider the need for admission or referral.
    • Consider a suspected cancer pathway referral (for an appointment within 2 weeks) for women with suspected gynaecological cancer. See the CKS topic on Gynaecological cancers - recognition and referral for detailed information.
    • Arrange referral (for same day assessment) to a genito-urinary medicine (GUM) clinic for investigation and management for women with suspected pelvic inflammatory disease (PID).
      • Arrange urgent admission for women with suspected PID who are pregnant or have severe symptoms and signs (such as nausea, vomiting, and a fever greater than 38°C). See the CKS topic on Pelvic inflammatory disease for more information.
    • Consider referral to GUM clinic for further investigation if: 
      • Chlamydia, gonorrhoea, or trichomoniasis is suspected or confirmed (trichomoniasis should always be managed in GUM clinic).
      • Symptoms are recurrent or persistent.
      • There is doubt about the diagnosis.
    • Arrange referral to a GUM clinic for partner notification for women with microbiologically confirmed:
      • Gonorrhoea.
      • Chlamydia.
      • Trichomoniasis.
  • If admission or referral is not indicated, manage the woman in primary care.
    • Manage infective causes of abnormal vaginal discharge.
      • For women with suspected bacterial vaginosis or vaginal candidiasis, prescribe empirical antibiotic treatment. See the CKS topics on Bacterial vaginosis and Candida - female genital for more information on treatment.
      • For women with cervicitis, treat for chlamydia while awaiting swab results. See the CKS topic on Chlamydia - uncomplicated genital for more information. 
      • For women with suspected PID if same day treatment in a GUM clinic is not possible, prescribe empirical antibiotic treatment. See the CKS topic on Pelvic inflammatory disease for more information.
      • Note that empirical antibiotics while awaiting swab results are not required for women at increased risk of a sexually transmitted infection (STI), if they do not have any clinical features suggestive of infection.
    • Manage non-infective causes of vaginal discharge, where possible, or refer appropriately.
    • For women with no identifiable infective or non-infective causes of vaginal discharge, and no clinical clues from history  and examination, reassure that the discharge is probably physiological.
    • Advise women on:
      • Basic personal hygiene.
      • Avoidance of feminine hygiene products (such as douches and vaginal washes) and tight, synthetic clothing.
      • Safe sexual behaviours and practices.
    • Provide additional information on vaginal discharge.
      • Patient information on Vaginal discharge is available on the NHS website (www.nhs.uk).

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent: These recommendations are largely based on the guidelines Sexually Transmitted Infections in Primary Care 2013 (RCGP/BASHH) published on behalf of the Royal College of General Practitioners (RCGP) and the British Association for Sexual Health and HIV (BASHH) [Lazaro, 2013] and Management and laboratory diagnosis of Abnormal Vaginal Discharge: Quick Reference Guide for Primary Care published by Public Health England (PHE) [PHE, 2013] and on review articles on vaginal discharge [Spence, 2007; Colver, 2013; Fahami, 2013; Powell, 2015; BMJ, 2017].
